item.title: He Was Right About the Territory. The Map Is Still Being Drawn.
item.description: In 1968, Herbert Fröhlich published a paper in the International Journal of Quantum Chemistry proposing that biological macromolecules could exhibit long-range coherent quantum oscillations, driven by metabolic energy, analogous to Bose-Einstein condensation. The prediction was specific: above a critical threshold of energy input, a biological system driven far from thermal equilibrium would channel excess energy into a single quantum mode, producing collective oscillations in the terahertz range. He called it a condensate. The community eventually called it Fröhlich coherence.

item.title: The Navy Published Their Nothing. Here's Why That's the Tell.
item.description:
The Biefeld-Brown effect is real. Capacitors under high voltage produce thrust. This is reproducible, measurable, and documented. You can build one in your kitchen if you’re comfortable working around high voltages, which you probably shouldn’t be, but the physics works.

The question — and it’s been the question since Thomas Townsend Brown started running experiments in the 1920s — is whether that thrust is ion wind or something stranger.

Ion wind is what happens when you ionize air near an electrode and the resulting ion flow drags neutral air molecules with it. It’s real, well-understood, and completely mundane. The “something stranger” is what Brown spent sixty years claiming: a direct coupling between electrostatic fields and gravity. Electrogravitics. A reactionless drive that would make rockets look like steam engines.

item.title: One Bad Afternoon. Twenty-Three Years of Consequences.
item.description:
Birmingham International Airport, 1984.

A small elevated shuttle is running a 600-metre track at 42 km/h, carrying passengers between the terminal and the railway station. No wheels touching rails. No combustion. A linear induction motor — a horizontal electromagnetic field dragging a reaction plate through space — doing what wheels and pistons used to do.

The world’s first commercial maglev people mover. Running. Doing its job.

The man most responsible for the engineering principles underneath it wasn’t there. He was eight years into the institutional exile that had started with one bad afternoon in 1974.

item.title: The Orgone Question Can Wait. The Book Burning Can't.
item.description:
On August 23, 1956, the United States government burned books in New York City.

Not metaphorically. Not through censorship or suppression or the quiet suffocation of distribution. Physically. Six tons of books, journals, and scientific papers fed into the Gansevoort Incinerator on 25th Street, under FDA supervision, while the man who wrote them sat in federal prison awaiting his appeal.

There’s a reason you don’t know this. Not because it was hidden. It’s in the record. It’s cited as one of the worst instances of censorship in American history. But the books belonged to Wilhelm Reich, and if you say “Wilhelm Reich” to most people, they say “orgone” — and once you say “orgone,” the book burning tends to get buried in the argument about whether orgone energy is real.
